qas.question: Describe Gaddafi's first experience with education.

answers.text: a religious nature, imparted by a local Islamic teacher

qas.question: In addition to gaining an education, describe how Gaddafi managed to attend school 20 miles from his family.

answers.text: During the week Gaddafi slept in a mosque, and at weekends walked 20 miles to visit his parents

qas.question: How did Gaddafi deal with peer pressure regarding his cultural background?

answers.text: Bullied for being a Bedouin, he was proud of his identity and encouraged pride in other Bedouin children.

qas.question: When Gaddafi's family moved to Sabha, describe his educational experiences in secondary school.

answers.text: Gaddafi was popular at school; some friends made there received significant jobs in his later administration, most notably his best friend Abdul Salam Jalloud.
where his father worked as a caretaker for a tribal leader while Muammar attended secondary school, something neither parent had done.

qas.question: Why was Gaddafi made fun of in elementary school?

answers.text: Bullied for being a Bedouin, he was proud of his identity and encouraged pride in other Bedouin children.

qas.question: How did Gaddafi manage to attend elementary school so far from home?

answers.text: During the week Gaddafi slept in a mosque, and at weekends walked 20 miles to visit his parents.
while Muammar attended secondary school, something neither parent had done.

qas.question: How did his early relationships play a role later when Gaddafi  became a ruler?

answers.text: Gaddafi was popular at school; some friends made there received significant jobs in his later administration, most notably his best friend Abdul Salam Jalloud.
Education in Libya was not free, but his father thought it would greatly benefit his son despite the financial strain.
